abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are highly satisfactory
            in outcome, sustainability, performances by both the Bank,
            and Borrower, as well as in the substantial institutional
            development impact. A number of lessons address the
            following: 1) The significance of competent counterpart
            cannot be emphasized enough, for success is greatly
            facilitated by competent staff, exemplified by the Latvian
            Road Administration (LAR), and Ministry of Transport
            competencies. 2) Likewise, a maximum degree of competition
            is necessary to attain efficient contract works, proven by
            the introduction of international competitive bidding, which
            intensified competition, reducing unit costs by thirty
            percent over the life of the project. This is best achieved
            in road operations, when both local, and international firms
            compete, but with bidding packages sufficiently subdivided,
            so that local firms with limited financial capacity, can
            also participate. 3) As experience indicates, project
            simplicity leads to success. This was reflected by the
            project's single counterpart agency, LAR, responsible
            for implementation of project components, which simplified
            both preparation, and supervision. 4) The "second
            generation" Road Fund in Latvia, demonstrated the
            recognition, and support of the public, while placing road
            management on a sound commercial basis, fostering an
            important role in meeting European integration requirements.
            5) The involvement of highly developed countries in
            Bank-financed projects, prods international integration,
            given the availability of grants for technical assistance to
            support reform, thus re-integrating the economy into the
            international community.
